children.text: [Template] A founder's guide to pricing your first VC round

This template was created by our co-founder Nuno, as a guide on how to understand and price your first fundraising round. It's quite a complex topic that a lot of founders struggle with, so we dissect it down to help you better understand the numbers behind the terms.

You can duplicate this template and start editing to customize it to your circumstances.

When the first term sheet arrives the round gets started. You should make sure you have shares in the region of the millions, so to avoid large volumes of fractional shares that can become challenging to manage.
It is a bit overwhelming, so let's dissect it.
Before you negotiate your first VC round, you might have a simple cap table like the below:

Next comes the price of the round. This translates to a price per share. However, the language varies significantly and can get quite confusing. You will start to hear terms like post-money, pre-money and ESOP (Employee Stock Option Pool)

For now, let's start by calculating how many shares will the investors get in the business for their capital:

The VCs are effectively buying 30% of your business. Typically, VC's try to buy between 20-30% of a business at each round. Founder and employee dilution are important to calculate and understand as you raise each subsequent round.
But, to look at dilution properly,  let's get back to the ESOP (employee stock option pool).
The employee stock option pool is a vital part of the price negotiation.
Both founders and investors are likely aligned in wanting a sufficient ESOP to compensate and attract early employees.

However, to be able to give stock options to your employees, you need to create a pool of shares from which those options will be given. In other words, you have to issue those shares when you get your investment.
Technically, they dilute all existing shareholders’ ownership. But, investors often insist that you create a pool
they invest, so your first employee option pool usually only dilutes your shares. And, dilution can start to add up quickly if you don't keep track.

Typically, options pools are anywhere from 10% to 15% of the Founder Shares.
